standard_metadata.standard_description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.

hints.content: $391 \times 7$ and $39.1\times 0.7$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.
Let's multiply $391 \times 7$.    Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $39.1 \times 0.7$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $39.1 \times 0.7$.  $\begin{align} 39.1 \times 0.7 &\approx 40\times 1\\\\ &\approx 40 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $2{,}737$ to get a product close to $40$?
$64 \times 53$ and $0.64\times 5.3$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.
Let's multiply $64 \times 53$.    Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.64\times 5.3$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.64 \times 5.3$.  $\begin{align} 0.64\times 5.3 &\approx 1\times 5\\\\ &\approx 5 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $3{,}392$ to get a product close to $5$?
$86 \times 22$ and $0.86\times 2.2$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.
Let's multiply $86 \times 22$.    Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.86 \times 2.2$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.86 \times 2.2$.  $\begin{align} 0.86 \times 2.2 &\approx 1\times 2\\\\ &\approx 2 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $1{,}892$ to get a product close to $2$?
$232 \times 56$ and $2.32\times 5.6$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.
Let's multiply $232 \times 56$.    Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $2.32 \times 5.6$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{2}32&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonD{5}6}&\\ 12&\quad6\times2\text{ ones}\\ {180}&\quad {6} \times {3\text{ tens}}\\ {1{,}200}&\quad {6} \times {2\text{ hundreds}}\\ {100}&\quad {50} \times {2\text{ ones}}\\ {1{,}500}&\quad {50} \times {3\text{ tens}}\\ \underline{{}+\greenE{10{,}000}}&\quad \maroonD{50} \times \blueE{2\text{ hundreds}}\\ \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 232&\\ \underline{{} \times 56}&\\ \purpleD{12}&\quad6\times2\text{ ones}\\ \purpleD{180}&\quad {6} \times {3\text{ tens}}\\ \purpleD{1{,}200}&\quad {6} \times {2\text{ hundreds}}\\ \purpleD{100}&\quad {50} \times {2\text{ ones}}\\ \purpleD{1{,}500}&\quad {50} \times {3\text{ tens}}\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{10{,}000}}&\quad {50} \times {2\text{ hundreds}}\\ 12{,}992 \end{align}$  $232 \times 56 = 12{,}992$

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $2.32 \times 5.6$.  $\begin{align} 2.32 \times 5.6 &\approx 2\times 6\\\\ &\approx 12 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $12{,}992$ to get a product close to $12$?

$\begin{align} \blueE{1}{,}526&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonD{3}9}&\\ {54}&\quad {9} \times {6\text{ ones}}\\ {180}&\quad{9} \times {2\text{ tens}}\\ {4{,}500}&\quad {9} \times 5\text{ hundreds}\\ {9{,}000}&\quad {9} \times {1\text{ thousand}}\\ {180}&\quad {30} \times {6\text{ ones}}\\ {600}&\quad {30} \times{2\text{ tens}}\\ {15{,}000}&\quad {30} \times {5\text{ hundreds}}\\ \underline{{}+\greenE{30{,}000}}&\quad \maroonD{30} \times \blueE{1\text{ thousand}}\\ \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 1{,}526&\\ \underline{{} \times 39}&\\ \purpleD{54}&\quad {9} \times {6\text{ ones}}\\ \purpleD{180}&\quad{9} \times {2\text{ tens}}\\ \purpleD{4{,}500}&\quad {9} \times 5\text{ hundreds}\\ \purpleD{9{,}000}&\quad {9} \times {1\text{ thousand}}\\ \purpleD{180}&\quad {30} \times {6\text{ ones}}\\ \purpleD{600}&\quad {30} \times{2\text{ tens}}\\ \purpleD{15{,}000}&\quad {30} \times {5\text{ hundreds}}\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{30{,}000}}&\quad {30} \times {1\text{ thousand}}\\ 59{,}514 \end{align}$  $39 \times 1{,}526 = 59{,}514$
